title-group.article-title: A High Prevalence of Carotid Artery Stenosis in Male Patients Older Than 65 Years, Irrespective of Presenting Clinical Manifestation of Atherosclerotic Diseases

article-meta.aff: 1Department of General Internal Medicine, Radboud University, Medical Centre Nijmegen, The Netherlands
2Department of Cardiology, Radboud University, Medical Centre Nijmegen, The Netherlands
3Department of Neurology, Radboud University, Medical Centre Nijmegen, The Netherlands
4Department of Surgery, Vrije Universiteit Medical Center, Amsterdam, The Netherlands

author-notes.corresp: Sebastian J. H. Bredie, Department of General Internal Medicine, Radboud University, Medical Centre Nijmegen, Postbus 9101, 6500 HB Nijmegen, The Netherlands. Email: s.bredie@aig.umcn.nl

abstract.p: This study investigated the prevalence of carotid artery stenosis (CS) and the association with various risk factors in male patients (>65 years) diagnosed with cardiovascular diseases. Duplex sonography of the carotid arteries was performed in 434 of 473 eligible patients of whom 118 (27.8%) patients had significant CS ≥50%. The prevalence and severity of CS did not differ between patients who presented with neurological symptoms or acute coronary syndrome/peripheral artery disease (30.8% vs 25.9%, respectively). Among patients with CS, a higher rate of current smoking, a higher systolic blood pressure, and a lower glomerular filtration rate were observed compared with patients without CS. A history of coronary artery bypass graft was a significant predictor of the presence of CS (P = .003, odds ratio [OR] = 2.70 [1.40-5.19]). The prevalence of CS in elderly males with manifest atherosclerotic disease is high, irrespective of presenting clinical manifestation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis (CS) is an important cause of morbidity and mortality. 1,2 The annual stroke risk has been reported to be approximately 0.2% in the general population 3 and 2% to 5% in patients with severe asymptomatic CS, 4,5 increasing to 5% in patients presenting with transient ischemic attack (TIA). 6 Furthermore, mortality with internal CS (ICS)-related stroke may be as high as 45% during follow up of 1.2 years. 7 However, a prevalence of only about 0% to 3.1% of severe asymptomatic CS has been observed in the general population. 8

Carotid artery stenosis is a manifestation of atherosclerotic diseases and its coexistence with coronary artery diseases (CADs) 9 and peripheral artery diseases (PADs) 10 is considerable. In the patients with PAD, the prevalence of ICS is up to 28%. 10
–14 The presence of carotid bruits is associated with higher rate of myocardial infarction (MI) morbidity and mortality. 15 The European Society for Vascular Surgery recommended aggressive preventive approaches for the patients with CS. 16

Significant CS (≥50%) was observed in 59% of patients who underwent preoperative carotid artery duplex scanning before coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) procedure. 17 Furthermore, increased carotid plaque thickness is associated with an increased risk of combined vascular events compared with the participants without carotid plaque. 9 Either symptomatic or asymptomatic CS is associated with atherosclerotic vascular wall abnormalities, 18,19 male gender, 20,21 and established predisposing risk factors for atherosclerosis. 20 –22 Furthermore, the prevalence of CS is associated with hypercholesterolemia, 23 diabetes mellitus, 24 high systolic blood pressure, 25 and tobacco smoking. 26 Also, glomerular filtration rate (GFR), most likely as a marker of glomerular atherosclerosis, was found as an independent predictor of carotid atherosclerosis in patients with CAD. 27

Because of high sensitivity and specificity, noninvasive screening of CS by ultrasonography is applicable to investigate the presence and severity of atherosclerotic disease. 28 Duplex ultrasonography which is performed without additional imaging is cost effective in the selection of symptomatic patients suitable for endarterectomy. 29 Screening for treatable causes of potential stroke can be cost effective, depending on the population at risk. The prevalence of severe CS increases with age and gender. 20 Therefore, screening for causes of stroke, which may have consequences for treatment, seems most effective in male patients in the age above 65 years with manifest atherosclerotic disease. 30

In the current study, we evaluated the prevalence and severity of CS in elderly male patients referred for TIA/ischemic stroke, acute coronary syndrome (ACS), or PAD, in order to determine the efficacy of screening in these specific groups. Furthermore, we evaluated the predictive value of predisposing risk factors in either symptomatic (referred for TIA or ischemic stroke) or asymptomatic patients (no TIA or stroke) in this population.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Duplex screening of the carotid artery was performed using routine procedures. According to the results, individuals were categorized into CS(+) in case of a sonography-defined stenosis ≥50% (50%-70% stenosis: peak systolic velocities [PSVs] ratio 2-4 and/or PSVs <210 cm/s, and end-diastolic velocity [EDV] <100 cm/s; and 70%-99% stenosis: PSVs ratio ≥4 and/or PSVs >210 cm/s, and EDV >100 cm/s) in 1 of the major branches of left or right ICA or external carotid artery (ECA) or common carotid artery (CCA), and CS(−) in case of normal carotid arteries with stenosis <50% (PSVs ratio <2 and/or PSVs <125 cm/s). All patients who had ischemic stroke or TIA in the recent 6 months before referral were considered to be “symptomatic.” All other male patients were considered to be “asymptomatic.” None of the patients developed TIA/stroke after initial referral.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The data were evaluated using SPSS 16, with descriptive statistics (mean, median, standard deviation [SD], and interquartile range) determined for all variables. Normally distributed values were evaluated by t test and chi-square test, whereas nonparametric tests were used in the case of skewed distribution. Logistic regression analysis was used to predict the presence of CS on the basis of relevant risk factors. A P < .05 (2-tailed) was considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The mean age of the 434 evaluated participants was 68.3 ± 6.9 years. In all, 118 (27.8%) were CS(+) and 316 (72.8%) participants were CS(−). There was no significant difference in mean age, body mass index, or waist circumference between the 2 groups (Table 1). Patients with CS(+) were more frequently smokers (36.4% vs 24.7%, P = .01) and presented with higher systolic blood pressure compared with CS(−) (149.7 ± 21.8 vs 144.1 ± 21.8, P = .02; Table 1). Alcohol intake (>5 u/week), diastolic blood pressure, lipid profile, and serum creatinine levels did not show significant differences between the 2 groups. However, calculated GFR was lower in patients with CS(+) compared with CS(−) (91 [82-108] vs 88 [77-105] mL/min, P = .005; Table 1).

caption.p: Clinical and Biochemical Characteristics of the Patients With or Without Carotid Artery Stenosis (CS).a

fn.p: Abbreviations: CS(+) and CS(−), patients with and without documented carotid artery stenosis (CS, on duplex sonography); BMI, body mass index; BP, blood pressure; HDL-C, high-density lipoprotein–cholesterol; LDL-C, low-density lipoprotein–cholesterol; GFR, glomerular filtration rate.
a Values expressed as mean ± SD for normally distributed data, and median and interquartile range for nonnormally distributed data; the GFR was calculated using the Cockroft-Gault equation.

sec.p: Patients with CS(+) had a more frequent medical history of CABG than those with CS(−) (17.8% vs 7.6%, P = .001). However, history of other cardiovascular diseases did not differ significantly between the 2 groups.

Of the 118 patients with CS, 99 (83.9%) had ICS. The number of ECA and CCA stenoses was 15 (12.7%) and 4 (3.4%), respectively (Table 2). Regarding to the severity of stenosis, we found that 44 (37.3%) patients with CS had 70% to 99% stenosis in the ICA. Six (5.08%) and 1 (0.08%) of CS patients showed 70% to 99% stenosis in ECA and CCA, respectively (Table 2).

caption.p: The Involvement and Degree of Stenosis of Different Branches of the Carotid Artery.

tr.td: The carotid branch with the highest degree of stenosis (n = 118)

fn.p: Abbreviations: ICA, internal carotid artery; ECA, external carotid artery; CCA, common carotid artery.

sec.p: Multiple logistic regression analysis was performed to assess the relative contribution of selected parameters (age, GFR, creatinine, systolic blood pressure, history of CABG, and smoking) to the presence of sonography-defined CS (Table 3). History of CABG proved to be an independent significant predictor of CS (P = .003, OR = 2.70 [1.40-5.19]; Table 3).

caption.p: Assessment of the Relative Contribution of Selected Parameters to the Presence of Carotid Artery Stenosis (CS).a

fn.p: Abbreviations: CABG, coronary artery bypass graft; CS, carotid artery stenosis; GFR, glomerular filtration rate.

a Adjusted odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (95% CIs) obtained from multiple logistic regression. A P < .05 was considered significant. The GFR was calculated using the Cockroft-Gault equation.

sec.p: The CS(+) patients with a 50% to 70% stenosis in 1 of the branches of the carotid artery were significantly older than patients in CS(−) group (70.8 ± 7.1 vs 67.8 ± 7, P = .027; Table 4). Glomerular filtration rate levels in patients with 50% to 70% stenosis in 1 of the branches of carotid artery were significantly lower than the patients in CS(−) group (68.9 ± 18.5 vs 82.3 ± 22.9, P = .001; Table 4). Creatinine levels of patients with occlusion of carotid artery was significantly higher than the group with 70% to 99% stenosis (120.8 ± 31.9 vs 90.1 ± 21.7 μmol/L, P = .008; Table 4).

caption.p: Risk Factors in Different Groups of the Patients With and Without Carotid Artery Stenosis (CS) by Different Degrees of CS.

fn.p: Abbreviations: CS, carotid artery stenosis; BMI, body mass index; HDL-C, high-density lipoprotein–cholesterol; LDL-C, low-density lipoprotein–cholesterol; glomerular filtration rate, calculated using the Cockroft-Gault equation.
a Age of the patients with 50% to 70% of carotid stenosis was significantly higher than the patients in CS(−) group (post hoc test, P = .02).
b Creatinine level of the patients with occlusion (100% CS; n = 8) was significantly higher than the group with 70% to 99% of stenosis (post hoc test, P = .008).
c GFR of the patients with 50% to 70% CS was significantly lower than the patients in CS(−) group (post hoc test, P = .001).

sec.p: In our population, 36 (30.5%) of 118 patients with CS were symptomatic (presented with TIA or stroke). However, 81 (25.6%) patients without CS also presented with TIA or stroke. There was no significant association between the presence of CS and CS-related symptoms (TIA or stroke) in this population (Table 5). Comparisons between traditional risk factors for CS patients with and without presenting neurological symptoms did not show any significant difference (P > .05; Table 6).

caption.p: Percentage of Symptomatic Patients With and Without Carotid Artery Stenosis (CS).a

fn.p: a There was no significant difference between the prevalence of CS in symptomatic or asymptomatic patients (chi-square test; P > .05).

caption.p: Clinical and Biochemical Characteristics of the Symptomatic and Asymptomatic Patients With Carotid Artery Stenosis (CS; n = 118).a

fn.p: Abbreviations: CS(+) and CS(−), patients with and without documented CS (based on duplex sonography); BMI, body mass index; BP, blood pressure; HDL-C, high-density lipoprotein–cholesterol; LDL-C, low-density lipoprotein–cholesterol; GFR, glomerular filtration rate, calculated using the Cockroft-Gault equation.

a Values expressed as mean ± SD for normally distributed data, and median and interquartile range for nonnormally distributed data. There were no significant differences between symptomatic and asymptomatic patients (P > .05).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In our study, 27.2% of male patients above the age of 65 with prior manifestation of atherosclerosis appeared to have CS (≥50%). This high percentage of the patients with CS in our study is directly related to the fact that 37% of the case mix was referred for TIA or stroke, in which CS is highly prevalent. 32,33 However, 82 (25.8%) of the 317 patients without TIA or stroke appeared to have CS >50%, of which 59 (13.6%) presented with severe CS (degree of stenosis >70%). Therefore, the difference in prevalence of CS ≥50% between patients with TIA/stroke and the patients with other manifestations of atherosclerotic disease (MI or PAD) seems clinically comparable (30.8% vs 25.8%, respectively).

Our findings are consistent with the results of a recent meta-analysis in patients with PAD, in which a prevalence of 28% asymptomatic CS (≥50%) was reported. 34 Yun et al also reported that the prevalence of ICS (≥70%) was 14% in patients with atherosclerotic lower extremity ischemia. 35

Several previous investigations showed that serum total cholesterol, 23 low-density lipoprotein–cholesterol, 36 and high-density lipoprotein–cholesterol 25 are independent predictors of CS. However, the protective effect depends on various aspects, such as lipid levels and duration of lipid-lowering therapy and other risk factors. In our study population, the use of lipid-lowering medication prior to the event was widespread or initiated directly after the event. Therefore, significant difference between the serum levels of components of lipid profile could not been detected in our study, because of an equal use of lipid-lowering drugs in both groups.

The systolic blood pressure was associated with the presence of CS in the male patients with manifest atherosclerotic diseases. Although blood pressure was treated in all patients in our study, the systolic blood pressure of the patients with CS remained significantly higher than the patients without CS. This finding that systolic blood pressure was independently associated with CS was reported by Mathiesen et al in a large cohort of patients screened for CS with duplex ultrasound. 25

We found a significant association between decreased GFR and presence of CS in male patients with manifest atherosclerotic diseases. Furthermore, GFR of the patients with 50% to 70% CS was lower than CS(−) patients. Glomerular filtration rate is an independent predictor of carotid atherosclerosis development in the patients with CAD. 27 However, the finding of a reduced GFR in the male CS patients has not being reported previously. The European Society of Cardiology guideline suggested an association between decreased GFR and increased peripheral arterial risk. 37 Lisowska et al demonstrated that decreased GFR is associated with preclinical stages of atherosclerotic changes, including carotid atherosclerosis. 38 Probably, systemic atherosclerotic disease in patients presenting with CS also influences glomerular function by concomitant atherosclerosis of the renal arteries. Moreover, diminished glomerular filtration function is generally related to increased systolic blood pressure, as observed in this population. Although linearity between CS severity and diminished GFR occurred, the predictive value of GFR for CS on an individual basis is limited. According to the beneficial effects of statins on GFR, 39 it can be recommended for CS which may prevent the development of CS with a systemic vascular effect. In our study most of the patients were on statin therapy after the major vascular events, therefore we are not able to assess the effects of statins on GFR levels. Further studies need to be done in this regard.

Our results did not confirm a marked relation between alcohol consumption and CS presence that is consistent with the findings of Zureik et al. 40 Mowbray et al also reported the association between intima–media thickness and alcohol consumption, only in women but not in men. 41 Although Hajat et al observed an association between alcohol consumption and TIA or stroke occurrence in a case–control study, 42 we were not able to observe this in these male patients with atherosclerosis.

Our results about the relationship between smoking and prevalence of CS are in accordance with the findings that demonstrated a higher percentage of smoking history in the patients with prior features of atherosclerosis and CS than the patients of the same population without CS. 26

According to our results, there were no significant difference between the existence of overt cardiovascular events (MI, cerebral bleeding, ischemia, TIA, and intermittent claudication) and presence of CS in the sample population with the history of manifest atherosclerosis. However, a significant predictive relation between previous CABG and prevalence of CS was observed.

Birincioğlu et al investigated 678 consecutive patients who underwent preoperative carotid artery duplex scanning before CABG procedure and found significant CS (≥50%) in 59% of the patients. 17 Therefore, the prelikelihood of CS, which may be severe, in CABG patients supports screening in this subset of patients. Remarkably, the presence of ischemic stroke or TIA did not differ significantly between our patients with or without CS. This finding indicates that CS screening for severe CS should not be restricted to symptomatic patients but may reveal equal amounts of severe CS in male patients presenting with MI and PAD.

So far, we could not detect predictive risk factors for symptomatic disease in the presence of CS, which however is in line with Dharmasaroja et al who did not find any significant difference between cardiovascular risk factors for symptomatic patients with or without CS. 26

Rigorous evaluation of male patients older than 65 years with manifest atherosclerotic disease reveals a high portion of significant CS, irrespective of presenting vascular symptoms. Systolic blood pressure, smoking, and decreased GFR level seem to be associated with the presence of CS in the patients with atherosclerotic disease, whereas a history of CABG may be independently predictive in atherosclerotic male patients. In more than 40% of the cases, this may have management consequences due to the severity of the stenosis. Based on this study, screening strategy cannot be refined by individual cardiovascular risk factors or symptoms of atherosclerotic disease other than previous CABG.

fn.label: Authors’ Note
fn.p: This work has not been presented in any congress.
